title: Joshua's Commission
shortSummary: Joshua 1 records God's commissioning of Joshua as the new leader of Israel following Moses' death. God commands Joshua to be strong and courageous as he leads the people across the Jordan River to possess the Promised Land, emphasizing obedience to the Law for success and blessing.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Transition of leadership from Moses to Joshua at the edge of the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Moses' minister and successor, appointed by God to lead Israel into the Promised Land.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The servant of the LORD who led Israel out of Egypt and received God's Law; his death marks the leadership transition.

keyCharacters.name: Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: Tribes who had already received land east of the Jordan and are called to support their brethren in conquering the rest of the land.

definitions.definition: A servant or attendant; in this context, Joshua served as Moses' aide and assistant.
The land promised by God to the descendants of Israel as their possession.
To deeply reflect on and study Scripture, focusing the mind and heart on God's Word.
Strength and bravery to face challenges, especially in obedience to God's commands.

outline.heading: God Commissions Joshua
outline.description: Following Moses' death, God speaks directly to Joshua, assuring him of divine presence and victory as he leads Israel into the Promised Land.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Strength and Obedience
outline.description: God commands Joshua to be strong and courageous, emphasizing strict adherence to the Law and continual meditation on Scripture as the key to success.

outline.heading: Joshua Prepares the People
outline.description: Joshua instructs the officers to prepare the people for crossing the Jordan within three days to possess the land God has given them.

outline.heading: Encouragement to the Eastern Tribes
outline.description: Joshua reminds the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh of their commitment to support their brethren in battle until all have rest and possession of their inheritance.

outline.heading: The People's Pledge of Obedience
outline.description: The people affirm their loyalty to Joshua, promising obedience as they had to Moses, with a stern warning against rebellion.

application: Trust God’s promises and presence when facing new challenges or leadership responsibilities.
Commit to daily meditation on Scripture to guide your decisions and actions.
Be strong and courageous in obeying God’s commands, even when the path ahead is uncertain.
Support and encourage fellow believers as they fulfill their God-given roles and callings.

keyVerses.text: There shall not any man be able to stand before thee all the days of thy life: as I was with Moses, so I will be with thee: I will not fail thee, nor forsake thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures Joshua of God's continual presence and support, a foundational promise for Christian confidence.

keyVerses.text: Only be thou strong and very courageous, that thou mayest observe to do according to all the law, which Moses my servant commanded thee: turn not from it to the right hand or to the left, that thou mayest prosper whithersoever thou goest.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the necessity of courage and strict obedience to God's law as the path to prosperity and success.

keyVerses.text: This book of the law shall not depart out of thy mouth; but thou shalt meditate therein day and night, that thou mayest observe to do according to all that is written therein: for then thou shalt make thy way prosperous, and then thou shalt have good success.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the importance of continual Scripture meditation for spiritual success and guidance.

keyVerses.text: Have not I commanded thee? Be strong and of a good courage; be not afraid, neither be thou dismayed: for the LORD thy God is with thee whithersoever thou goest.
keyVerses.significance: A powerful encouragement to trust God’s presence and not succumb to fear.
